facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 10 of 1950 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 10 of 1950. Appeal from a Judgment of the High Court

facts.text: Appeal arose from judgment of Bombay High Court by Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J. dated 29th March 1950 in Suit No. 24 of 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from a Judgment of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay  Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.  dated 29th March, 1950, in Suit No. 24 of 1950.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on December 20, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: 1950. December 20. The Court delivered Judgment as follows FAZL ALI J.--I have read the judgment

facts.text: Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 (Act XL of 1948) was enacted by Bombay State Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948  Act XL of 1948 , is ultra vires the Legislature of the State of Bombay

facts.text: Act creates additional civil court for Greater Bombay with jurisdiction over suits not exceeding certain value.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay City Civil Court Act purports to create in additional civil companyrt for Greater Bombay having jurisdic- tion to try, receive and dispose of all suits and other proceedings of a civil nature number exceeding a certain value

facts.text: Section 4 of the Act allows Provincial Government by notification to invest City Civil Court with jurisdiction up to Rs. 25,000.

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the exceptions specified in section 3, the Provincial Government, may by numberification in the Official Gazette, invest the City Civil Court with jurisdiction to receive, try and dispose of all suits

facts.text: Notification issued under section 4 on 20th January 1950 enhancing pecuniary limit to Rs. 25,000.

anchor.surface_text: in companytravention of a numberifi- cation dated the 20th January, 1950, issued under section 4 of the City Civil Court Act, under which suits up to the pecuniary limit of Rs. 25,000

facts.text: First respondent filed suit in Bombay High Court original side on 6th February 1950 against second respondent for Rs. 11,704-24 on promissory notes.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are that on the 6th February, 1950, the first respondent presented a plaint to the Prothonotary and Senior Master of the High Court for filing a summary suit against the second respondent to recover a sum of Rs. 11,704-24 alleged to be due under promissory numberes.

facts.text: Suit value Rs. 11,704 exceeded initial Rs. 10,000 limit but within enhanced Rs. 25,000.

anchor.surface_text: This suit was instituted in the High Court, in companytravention of a numberifi- cation dated the 20th January, 1950

facts.text: Bombay High Court held Act intra vires but section 4 ultra vires, so suit properly in High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The first and the third questions have been answered by the High Court in favour of the appellant and the second question has been answered in favour of the respondents.

facts.text: State of Bombay impleaded as party defendant in the suit.

anchor.surface_text: the State of Bombay, the appellant herein was on its own motion, made a party defendant.

facts.text: Plaint admitted by High Court judge on 23rd February 1950 holding section 4 ultra vires.

anchor.surface_text: On 23rd February, 1950, the learned Judge admitted the plaint holding that section 4 of the Act was ultra vires the Provincial Legislature

facts.text: Division Bench of High Court upheld single judge's view and returned suit for merits disposal.

anchor.surface_text: The Division Bench upheld the view of the Judge in Chambers and returned the cause to him for disposal on the merits.

facts.text: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, holding Act and section 4 valid, High Court without jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed.

facts.text: Act came into force on 10th May 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Bombay Act of 1948 came into force on 10th May, 1948.

facts.text: City Civil Court established to relieve congestion on Bombay High Court original side.

anchor.surface_text: It was companysidered expedient to establish an additional civil companyrt for Greater Bombay presumably with the object of relieving companygestion of work on the original side of the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Section 3 sets initial pecuniary jurisdiction at Rs. 10,000 for suits in Greater Bombay with exceptions.

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding anything companytained in any law, such companyrt shall have juris- diction to receive, try and dispose of all suits and other proceedings of a civil nature number exceeding ten thousand rupees in value, and arising within the Greater Bombay

facts.text: Section 12 bars High Court jurisdiction over suits cognisable by City Civil Court.

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding anything companytained in any law, the High Court shall number have jurisdiction to try suits and proceedings companynisable by the City Court

facts.text: High Court relied on its earlier decision in Mulchand v. Raman (51 B.L.R. 86) for Act's validity.

anchor.surface_text: On the first ques- tion the High Court placed reliance on its own earlier decision in Mulchand Kundanmal Jagtiani v. Raman Hiralal Shah 1

holdings.text: The Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 (Act XL of 1948) is intra vires the Legislature of the State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay City Civil Court Act purports to create in additional civil court for Greater Bombay having jurisdic- tion to try, receive and dispose of all suits and other proceedings of a civil nature not exceeding a certain value

holdings.reasoning_summary: Entry 1 List II confers general power over administration of justice including constitution of courts and general civil jurisdiction; special entries 53 List I and 2 List II do not limit it; pith and substance doctrine applies.

holdings.text: Section 4 of the Bombay City Civil Court Act, 1948 is intra vires and constitutes valid conditional legislation, not delegation of legislative power.

anchor.surface_text: section 4 which authorised the Provincial Government to enhance the jurisdiction of the City Court up to the limit of Rs. 25,000... the impugned provision is an instance of what the Privy Council has designated as conditional legislation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Legislature fixed policy (initial Rs10,000, max Rs25,000); government determines timing via notification; follows Queen v. Burah; distinguishes Jatindranath Gupta.

holdings.text: The Bombay High Court does not have jurisdiction to try the suit as it is cognisable by the City Civil Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, this appeal is allowed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sections 3,4,12 valid; suit value within City Court limit post-notification; High Court jurisdiction barred by s12.

holdings.text: Entry 1 of List II ('administration of justice; constitution and organisation of all courts') empowers Provincial Legislature to confer general civil jurisdiction on courts.

anchor.surface_text: Entries 1 and 2, List II -- 1 the administration of justice constitution and organisation of all courts except the Federal Court... The expression administration of justice has a wide meaning

holdings.reasoning_summary: Self-contained entry includes jurisdiction necessary for courts to function; pre-1935 practice; avoids anomalous results.

holdings.text: Entries 53 List I and 2 List II confer special/additional jurisdiction/powers re list matters, not ousting general jurisdiction under Entry 1 List II.

anchor.surface_text: The question then arises as to the exact meaning of entry 2 of List II and entry 53 of List I, which are said to militate against the above construction. These entries, in my opinion, confer special powers

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction; examples from statutes; legislative practice; each entry independent.

holdings.text: The pith and substance of the Act is constitution of courts and administration of justice (List II); incidental encroachment on List I not fatal.

anchor.surface_text: the doctrine of pith and substance in answer to the argument on behalf of the respondent. But that doctrine, while it often furnishes the key to the solution

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prafulla Kumar v. Bank of Commerce; extent immaterial if pith provincial; Act constitutes court with general jurisdiction.

holdings.text: City Civil Court has jurisdiction to try suits on promissory notes (List I Entry 28) absent central legislation barring it.

anchor.surface_text: Perhaps, it will be simpler to deal at this stage with the third question, namely, whether the Bombay City Civil Court has jurisdiction to try a suit based on a promissory note.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from general jurisdiction under List II Entry 1; no special central bar; Prafulla Kumar analogy.

holdings.text: Section 12 barring High Court jurisdiction over City Court cognisable suits is valid.

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding anything contained in any law, the High Court shall not have jurisdiction to try suits and proceedings cognisable by the City Court

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from competence to constitute courts with jurisdiction under List II.

holdings.text: Pre-1935 legislative practice of conferring general jurisdiction on provincial courts supports interpretation of List II powers.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Known to framers; no radical change intended; Croft v. Dunphy.

holdings.text: Respondent's interpretation leads to anomalous results, e.g., no provincial jurisdiction over List I matters like carriage by air until central law.

precedents.citation: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee and Others v. Bank of Commerce Limited Khulnal 1 1947 F.C.R.28

anchor.surface_text: the case of Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee and Others v. Bank of Commerce Limited Khulnal  1 , in which the arguments of the  1  1947 F.C.R.28. respondents before the Privy Council proceeded on the same lines as the arguments of the respondents before us. The question raised in that case was as to the validity of the Bengal Money-lenders Act, 1940, which limited the amount recoverable by a money-lender on his loans and interests on them, and prohibited the payments of sums larger than those permitted by the Act.

precedents.case_name: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee v. Bank of Commerce Ltd. Khulna
precedents.cited_proposition: Validity of provincial legislation affecting promissory notes incidentally; pith and substance is money-lending, not promissory notes

anchor.surface_text: As several of my learned companyleagues have pointed out, the case of Queen v. Burah  1 , the authority of which was number questioned before us, fully companyers the companytention raised, and the impugned provision is an instance of what the Privy Council has designated as companyditional legislation, and does number really delegate any legislative power but merely prescribes as to how effect is to be given to what the Legislature has already decided.

precedents.cited_proposition: Conditional legislation is valid; no delegation of legislative power when legislature fixes policy and conditions
precedents.cited_holding: Section allowing executive to extend Act territorially is conditional legislation, not delegation

anchor.surface_text: As some of the American Judges have remarked, there are many things upon which wise and useful legislation must depend which cannot be known to the law-making power and must therefore be the subject of enquiry and determination outside the halls of legislation  Field v. Clark  2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Legislature can make law conditional on future executive determination of facts

precedents.citation: Jitendranath Gupta v. The Province of Bihar 2 1949-50 F.C.R. 595

anchor.surface_text: I think that the present case stands well outside what was laid down by the Federal Court in Jitendranath Gupta v. The Province of Bihar, 2  as two of my companyleagues who were parties to the majority decision in that case have pointed out.

precedents.case_name: Jitendranath Gupta v. Province of Bihar

anchor.surface_text: The Bombay High Court in Mulchand v. Raman  1 , which was followed by the learned Judges in the present case, and the Attorney-General who adopted the same line before us, invoked the doctrine of pith and substance in answer to the argument on behalf of the respondent.

precedents.cited_proposition: Pith and substance doctrine for legislative competence on jurisdiction

precedents.citation: Stewart v. Brojendra Kishore 2 A.I.R. 1939 Cal. 628

anchor.surface_text: A similar difficulty in companystruing entry 4 of List III and entry 2 of List II arose in Stewart v. Brojendra Kishore  2  and led a Division Bench of the Calcutta High Court to companystrue the expression civil procedure occurring in the former entry in a limited sense as excluding jurisdiction and powers of companyrts.

precedents.cited_proposition: Civil procedure excludes jurisdiction due to specific entries

anchor.surface_text: After referring to the decision of the Judicial Committee in In re Marriage Reference 3  where marriage ,and divorce in the Dominion List was companystrued as excluding matters relating to the solemnisation of marriage

precedents.cited_proposition: Specific list entries exclude overlapping matters

anchor.surface_text: He placed reliance on the following observations of Gwyer C.J. in Aliqa Begums case  4  It would be practi- cally impossible for example to define each item in the Provincial List in such a way as to make it exclusive of every item in that list

precedents.cited_proposition: Legislative lists to be read broadly, including ancillary matters

anchor.surface_text: as pointed out by the Judicial Committee in the Khulna Bank case 1 . One of the questions their Lordships put to themselves in that case was Once it is determined that the pith and substance is money- lending, is the extent to which the federal field is invaded a material matter?

precedents.case_name: Prafulla Kumar Mukherjee v. Bank of Commerce Ltd. Khulna
precedents.cited_proposition: Pith and substance test; incidental encroachment allowed regardless of extent

anchor.surface_text: The test for determining whether in pith and substance a particular enactment falls within one list or another is further elucidated in a passage quoted with approval from Lefroys Treatise on Canadian Constitutional Law in the judgment of the Federal Court in the Bank of Commerce case 1 .

precedents.cited_proposition: Pith and substance depends on legislator's intent

anchor.surface_text: That it is legitimate to have regard to legislative practice in deter- mining the scope of legislative powers has been recognised in decisions of high authority  e.g., Croft v. Dunphy   1 ,

precedents.cited_proposition: Legislative practice aids interpretation of powers

anchor.surface_text: the High Court  Chagla C.J. and Tendolkar J.  held  1  the Act was intra vires, but  2  that section 4 which autho- rised the Provincial Government to enhance the jurisdiction of the City Court up to the limit of Rs. 25,000 amounted to a delegation of legislative power, and as such, was void and inoperative, with the result that the suit, which ex- ceeded Rs. 10,000 in  1 5 I.A. 178.
In Queen v. Burah 1 , section 9 of Act XXII of 1869, which was a piece of legislation analogous to section 4 of the City Civil Court Act, was held intra vires by their Lordships of the Privy Council.

precedents.cited_proposition: Power to extend territorial operation is conditional legislation

anchor.surface_text: Reference in this companynection may also be made to the decision of the Supreme Court of America in Field v. Clark 1  wherein referring to Lockes case 2  the following observations were made -

precedents.cited_proposition: Legislature cannot delegate power to make law but can condition on facts

anchor.surface_text: wherein referring to Lockes case 2  the following observations were made - To assert that a law is less than a law, because it is made to depend on a future event or act, is to rob the Legislature of the power to act wisely for the public wel- fare whenever a law is passed relating to a state of affairs number yet developed, or to things future and impossible to fully know.

precedents.cited_proposition: Laws conditional on future events are valid
